name: Prison Sentencing & Justice
explanation: The U.S. has the highest incarceration rate in the world. The debate is whether long sentences protect public safety through deterrence and incapacitation, or whether rehabilitation-focused approaches are more effective at reducing crime.

positionA.label: Longer sentences protect communities
positionA.statement: Longer sentences deter crime and keep dangerous people away from potential victims.

fallacyPrompts.starter: Reformers mostly live in safe suburbs and have never ___.
Reformers want to let dangerous criminals ___.
When we got tough on crime in the 90s, crime dropped. This proves ___.
Either we get serious about punishment or cities become ___.

soundPrompts.starter: Reformers make valid points about recidivism data, specifically ___.
The mechanism by which longer sentences deter crime is ___.
Regardless of who advocates for it, the evidence on sentence length and deterrence shows ___.

positionB.label: Rehabilitation reduces crime more
positionB.statement: Rehabilitation-focused sentencing is more effective at reducing recidivism and more humane.

fallacyPrompts.starter: Tough-on-crime advocates are just ___ who profit from ___.
They think locking people up forever will somehow ___.
If we keep building prisons, soon we'll have ___.

soundPrompts.starter: Those who favor longer sentences have valid concerns about public safety, including ___.
The specific mechanism by which rehabilitation reduces recidivism is ___.
Between maximum incarceration and no consequences, evidence supports ___.

cruxQuestions: Does severity of punishment actually deter crime?
Does rehabilitation work for violent offenders?
How do we balance punishment, deterrence, and rehabilitation?
What is the cost-benefit of incarceration vs. alternative programs?
